DEFINITION: An ion attached to the surface of a mineral
The composite gas comprising the Earth's atmosphere.
Material of an animal's body
Fine-grained solid material collected or filtered from the atmosphere
Outermost layers of stems and roots of woody plants
Solid organic material that forms part of a rock. It can usually be extracted from the rock with organic solvent.
A readily combustible organic rock containing more than 50% by weight and more than 70% by volume of carbonaceous material.
A solid of carbonaceous material derived from the destructive distillation of low-ash, low-sulphur bituminous coal.
A material that exists as gas in the subsurface but condenses into liquid at the surface.
Hard stony substance secreted by certain marine coelenterates as an external skeleton, typically forming large reefs in warm seas
A mixture of oil and water where oil is the main phase.
Fluid used for drill bit lubrication and return of ground rock material from the drill bit, e.g. mud.
Water from an estuary. Depending on the nature of the estuary, the salinity may vary spatially and temporally and range from fresh, brackish, seawater or hypersaline.
Waste material excreted from an animal
Plant leaves, especially tree leaves, considered as a group
A gas that that is exsolved from a liquid, such as water or oil, at the surface or under experimental conditions.

A sample containing a mixture of water and oil and may be an immulsion. Water is the main phase and hydrocarbons (e.g. benzene, toluene) are dissolved within the water. Synonym: formation water with oil
Hair or fur from an animal
Frozen, solid water.

Immobile organic matter that forms part of a rock. Kerogen cannot be extracted from the rock with organic solvents. Kerogen is concentrated in a pure form by removal of the mineral matter with strong acids (HCl, HF).

Deposit, commonly thin, or fragments of larger than sand size, spread over the land surface.  Its most common origin is as the coarse material left behind after fine material has been transported away by wind, or less commonly, sheet flow.
A sediment deposited in a body of standing fresh water

A marine sediment core that is collected together with the overlying water, as in a core incubation experiment, or a known area of seafloor and overlying water column, as in a chamber incubation experiment.
A rock that landed on Earth from an extraterrestrial source
A naturally occurring inorganic, crystalline, element or compound
A sample containing a mixture of rock and unconsolidated sediment.
Alluvium that is deposited outside an alluvial channel from flowing water which has overflowed from the channel.  It includes levees and back swamp deposits.
Any of the various dark heavy viscous and resinous substances obtained as a residue from the distillation of coal-tar or crude oil.
Stem, trunk, branch and twig material from a plant
Subsurface water in an interstice between grains in a marine sediment.
Rain water, collected before it hits the Earth's surface.
Oil that has been processed in an oil refinery.
Solid organic material that forms part of a rock. It is usually associated with coal and derived from the resinous material exuded from land plants.
The part of a plant that bears no leaves and typically, but not always, lies below the surface of the soil and is used for absorption of water and inorganic nutrients
Saline water from the Earth's seas and oceans
Gas that seeps at the Earths surface and recovered without the need for drilling.
Crude oil that seeps at the Earths surface and recovered without the need for drilling.
Crude oil and gas that seeps at the Earths surface and recovered without the need for drilling.
Atmospheric water vapour frozen into ice crystals and falling in light white flakes or lying on the ground as a white layer.
Unconsolidated mineral or organic material on the Earth's surface that serves as a natural medium for the growth of land plants.
The solid material left over after the pore water has been extracted from a sediment sample.
A sediment deposited in the bed of an active or perennial stream
Fresh or brackish water which occurs on the surface of a land mass (eg, rivers, creeks, lakes)
Sediment and biological particles collected from a water column that are separated by filtration and are not dissolved.
Material type is unknown
A sample that contains a mixture of materials from the seabed, possibly animal, vegetable, and mineral material.
A light coloured solid precipitated from either a hydrocarbon gas or oil

A naturally occurring complex liquid hydrocarbon, typically found as part of drilling activity, which after distillation and removal of impurities yields a range of combustible fuels, petrochemicals and lubricants.
Unspecified fluid material.
Synonym: formation water.  Part of the subsurface water that is in the zone of saturation, i.e., below the water table.  Can be located in one or several aquifers, aquicludes or aquitards.
Any non-hydrocarbon-based gas.
A fluid hydrocarbon that is a gas at the surface. In the subsurface this sample maybe be free of liquid hydrocarbons, contain dissolved liquid hydrocarbons, or be dissolved in oil.
A sediment (including porewater) deposited in a submarine or coastal, brackish or saline environment.
A consolidated aggregate of one or more minerals or other rocks
Any material of or excreted from an animal.  eg; animal tissue, faeces, hair
Typically unconsolidated or fragmental material, either transported or residual origin, which covers bedrock. Includes surficial duricrusts that cap bedrock.
Unconsolidated sedimentary material.
Any part of a plant whether it be moss, grass, sedge, or the roots, bark, twigs or leaves of trees and shrubs.
Any carbon-based material.
Any carbon-hydrogen fluid material
Any carbon-hydrogen based material.
Undivided saline, brackish, or fresh water.
